name: bamf_ct_liver_tumor
title: BAMF CT Liver and Tumor Seg (nnU-Net)

summary.description: An nnU-Net based model to segment liver and tumor from CT scans

inputs.label: Input Image
inputs.description: The CT scan of a patient.

details.name: AIMI CT Liver
details.type: nnU-Net (U-Net structure, optimized by data-driven heuristics)
details.cite: Murugesan, Gowtham Krishnan, Diana McCrumb, Mariam Aboian, Tej Verma, Rahul Soni, Fatima Memon, and Jeff Van Oss. The AIMI Initiative: AI-Generated Annotations for Imaging Data Commons Collections. arXiv preprint arXiv:2310.14897 (2023).

publications.title: The AIMI Initiative: AI-Generated Annotations in IDC Collections

use.title: Intended Use
use.text: This model is intended to perform liver and tumor segmentation in CT scans. The liver is a common site of primary (i.e. originating in the liver like hepatocellular carcinoma, HCC) or secondary (i.e. spreading to the liver like colorectal cancer) tumor development.

analyses.title: Quantitative Analyses
analyses.text: The model's performance was assessed using the Dice Coefficient, Hausdorff distance and NSD

evaluation.title: Evaluation Data
evaluation.text: The model was used to segment cases 509 from the Colorectal-Liver-Metastases [1] collection HCC-TACE-Seg [2]. 52 of those cases were randomly selected to be reviewed and corrected by a board-certified radiologist.

training.title: Training Data
training.text: 131 CT images from the LiTS 2017 and 131 CT images from the Medical Segmentation Decathlon datasets were used to train the nnU-Net model for liver and tumor segmentation. We utilized selected totalsegmentator outputs to develop anatomically informed model. The liver-CT model was trained to predict liver and liver tumors, as well as other abdominal organs including the duodenum, gallbladder, intestines, kidneys, lungs, pancreas, and spleen.

limitations.title: Limitations
limitations.text: The model has been trained and tested on scans acquired during clinical care of patients, so it might not be suited for a healthy population. The generalization capabilities of the model on a range of ages, genders, and ethnicities are unknown.
